(72)
s.t.C7,C8,(69a),(69b),(69c),(70b),(71b),(71c).s.t.subscript𝐶7subscript𝐶869a69b69c70b71b71c\displaystyle\text{ s.t.}\quad C_{7},C_{8},(\ref{transformCons1}),(\ref{transformCons2}),(\ref{transformCons3}),(\ref{transformCons5}),(\ref{fdRATequivalCons2_2}),(\ref{fdRATequivalCons2_3}). (72a)

Intuitively, ϑ≫0much-greater-thanitalic-ϑ0\vartheta\gg 0 penalizes the objective function when any Iv,z​(t)subscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t) is not either 00 or 111. Therefore, for a hefty ϑitalic-ϑ\vartheta, the pRB allocation parameter will need to be either 00 or 111 to minimize the objective function [55, 47].

Remark 8.

The optimization problem (72) belongs to the DC function programming because all four terms in the objective functions are convex, and the constraints span a convex set.

To that end, we use SCA to approximate the second term of (70a). Using Taylor expansion, we write the following for a feasible point Iv,z​(t,j)subscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡𝑗\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t,j).

∑v∈𝒰¯​(t)∑z=1Z(Iv,z​(t))2≥∑v∈𝒰¯​(t)∑z=1Z(Iv,z​(t,j))2+subscript𝑣¯𝒰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑧1𝑍superscriptsubscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡2limit-fromsubscript𝑣¯𝒰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑧1𝑍superscriptsubscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡𝑗2\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{v\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)}\sum\nolimits_{z=1}^{Z}(\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t))^{2}\geq\sum\nolimits_{v\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)}\sum\nolimits_{z=1}^{Z}(\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t,j))^{2}+
∑v∈𝒰¯​(t)∑z=1Z2​Iv,z​(t,j)​[Iv,z​(t)−Iv,z​(t,j)]=H​(𝐈~​(t,j)),subscript𝑣¯𝒰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑧1𝑍2subscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡𝑗delimited-[]subscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡subscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡𝑗𝐻~𝐈𝑡𝑗\displaystyle~{}\sum\nolimits_{v\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)}\sum\nolimits_{z=1}^{Z}2\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t,j)[\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t)-\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t,j)]=H(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\mathrm{I}}}(t,j)), (73)

where 𝐈~​(t,j)~𝐈𝑡𝑗\tilde{\boldsymbol{\mathrm{I}}}(t,j) is the set of all feasible points for all v𝑣v and z𝑧z. As such, given an initial feasible 𝐱~​(t,j)~𝐱𝑡𝑗\tilde{\mathbf{x}}(t,j), we obtain the upper bound of (72) via optimizing the following convex optimization problem.

minimize 𝐱~​(t,j)​U~​(t)+ϑ​[∑v∈𝒰¯​(t)∑z=1ZIv,z​(t)−H​(𝐈~​(t,j))],~𝐱𝑡𝑗minimize ~U𝑡italic-ϑdelimited-[]subscript𝑣¯𝒰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑧1𝑍subscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡𝐻~𝐈𝑡𝑗\displaystyle\underset{\tilde{\mathbf{x}}(t,j)}{\text{minimize }}~{}~{}\tilde{\mathrm{U}}(t)+\vartheta\Big{[}\!\!\sum\nolimits_{v\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)}\sum\nolimits_{z=1}^{Z}\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t)-H(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\mathrm{I}}}(t,j))\Big{]},\!\! (74)
s.t.C7,C8,(69a),(69b),(69c),(70b),(71b),(71c),s.t.subscript𝐶7subscript𝐶869a69b69c70b71b71c\displaystyle\text{ s.t.}\quad C_{7},C_{8},(\ref{transformCons1}),(\ref{transformCons2}),(\ref{transformCons3}),(\ref{transformCons5}),(\ref{fdRATequivalCons2_2}),(\ref{fdRATequivalCons2_3}), (74a)

where 𝐱~​(t,j)=[𝐈~​(t,j),𝐩​(t,j),𝐩~​(t,j)]~𝐱𝑡𝑗~𝐈𝑡𝑗𝐩𝑡𝑗~𝐩𝑡𝑗\tilde{\mathbf{x}}(t,j)=[\tilde{\boldsymbol{\mathrm{I}}}(t,j),\mathbf{p}(t,j),\tilde{\mathbf{p}}(t,j)] and H​(𝐈~​(t,j))𝐻~𝐈𝑡𝑗H(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\mathrm{I}}}(t,j)) is the global underestimation of ∑v∈𝒰¯​(t)∑z=1Z(Iv,z​(t))2subscript𝑣¯𝒰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑧1𝑍superscriptsubscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡2\sum\nolimits_{v\in\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)}\sum\nolimits_{z=1}^{Z}(\mathrm{I}_{v,z}(t))^{2}.

Note that (74) is convex and can be solved efficiently using existing solvers such as CVX [46]. Particularly, we use Algorithm 4 and CVX to solve (74) iteratively. Note that (74) has 3​(|𝒰¯​(t)|×Z)3¯𝒰𝑡𝑍3(|\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)|\times Z) decision variables and 4​(|𝒰¯​(t)|×Z)+2​|𝒰¯​(t)|+Z+14¯𝒰𝑡𝑍2¯𝒰𝑡𝑍14(|\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)|\times Z)+2|\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)|+Z+1 constraints. Besides, in the worst-case, |𝒰¯​(t)|=Z¯𝒰𝑡𝑍|\bar{\mathcal{U}}(t)|=Z. Moreover, we need to run Algorithm 3 to get the required scheduling decisions before solving (74). As such the time complexity of running Algorithm 4 for J𝐽J iterations is 𝒪​(27​J​Z6​(4​Z2+3​Z+1)+|𝒰​(t)|2+Z)𝒪27𝐽superscript𝑍64superscript𝑍23𝑍1superscript𝒰𝑡2𝑍\mathcal{O}\big{(}27JZ^{6}(4Z^{2}+3Z+1)+|\mathcal{U}(t)|^{2}+Z\big{)} [47]. Moreover, our SCA-based solutions of (48) and (74) converge to locally optimal solutions of the original problems (34) and (64), respectively [47, 55].

Remark 9 (VEFL Summary).

At the beginning of a VEFL round k𝑘k, each CV reports its ηvminsuperscriptsubscript𝜂𝑣min\eta_{v}^{\mathrm{min}}, ηvmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝜂𝑣max\eta_{v}^{\mathrm{max}}, Pvmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑣maxP_{v}^{\text{max}}, evbud​(k)subscriptsuperscriptebud𝑣𝑘\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{bud}}_{v}(k), DvsubscriptD𝑣\mathrm{D}_{v} and ξv​(lv​(k),ηv​(k))subscript𝜉𝑣subscript𝑙𝑣𝑘subscript𝜂𝑣𝑘\xi_{v}(l_{v}(k),\eta_{v}(k)) to the server as part of the SLA. The server solves (48) to jointly optimize 𝟏​(k)1𝑘\boldsymbol{1}(k), 𝐥​(k)𝐥𝑘\boldsymbol{l}(k) and 𝛈​(k)𝛈𝑘\boldsymbol{\eta}(k). It then sends the most recent global model 𝛚ksubscript𝛚𝑘\boldsymbol{\omega}_{k}, lv∗​(k)superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑣𝑘l_{v}^{*}(k)’s and ηv∗​(k)superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑣𝑘\eta_{v}^{*}(k)’s to the selected CVs. Each CV uses the optimized ηv∗​(k)superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑣𝑘\eta_{v}^{*}(k) to train the received ML model for lv∗​(k)superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑣𝑘l_{v}^{*}(k) local rounds on its local dataset. The server and the CVs work together to receive the CVs’ locally trained models 𝛚v,k+1subscript𝛚𝑣𝑘1\boldsymbol{\omega}_{v,k+1}’s. More specifically, the server keeps track of the remaining payload buffer 𝐐​(t)𝐐𝑡\mathbf{Q}(t), which essentially tells it how much of 𝛚v,k+1subscript𝛚𝑣𝑘1\boldsymbol{\omega}_{v,k+1}’s are yet to be received. Recall that the server estimated the worst-case required number of offloading time slots t¯vtxsuperscriptsubscript¯t𝑣tx\bar{\mathrm{t}}_{v}^{\mathrm{tx}} and determined the VEN slot τ​(k)𝜏𝑘\tau(k) from which it shall start receiving the 𝛚v,k+1subscript𝛚𝑣𝑘1\boldsymbol{\omega}_{v,k+1}’s. The server makes the payload offloading scheduling decisions based on Algorithm 3 from this slot τ​(k)𝜏𝑘\tau(k). It then solves (66) to optimize the transmission power if only one CV is scheduled. Otherwise, it solves (74) to optimize the pRB and power allocation jointly. The scheduled CVs then receives their Iv,z∗​(t)superscriptsubscriptI𝑣𝑧𝑡\mathrm{I}_{v,z}^{*}(t)’s and Pv,z∗​(t)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑣𝑧𝑡P_{v,z}^{*}(t)’s from the server, and continue offloading their 𝛚v,k+1subscript𝛚𝑣𝑘1\boldsymbol{\omega}_{v,k+1}’s. To that end, the server updates the global model based on its aggregation rule defined in (III-A) and repeats the above processes for the next round.

V Simulation Results and Discussions

V-A Simulation Setting

For our RoI, we use the real-world map information of downtown Raleigh, NC, USA, from OpenStreetMap777https://www.openstreetmap.org. We then use SUMO to model practical microscopic mobility as presented in Section II-A. We repeat our simulation process for 555 times to get the average performance. The VEN is simulated for 200020002000 seconds in each of these repeats. There are 293293293, 297297297, 299299299, 292292292 and 287287287 unique CVs, respectively in these 555 repeats. Besides, the total CVs present in the VEN slots varies. Each CV’s minimum and maximum CPU frequencies are selected randomly from [1×103,5×103]1superscript1035superscript103[1\times 10^{3},5\times 10^{3}] Hz and [1.9×109,2.8×109]1.9superscript1092.8superscript109[1.9\times 10^{9},2.8\times 10^{9}] Hz, respectively. The energy budget, required CPU cycle to process per bit data, per unit energy cost and ϕ¯vsubscript¯italic-ϕ𝑣\bar{\phi}_{v}s are randomly chosen from [20,30]2030[20,30] Joules, [20,30]2030[20,30], [5,10]510[5,10] units and [10,20]1020[10,20] units, respectively. For the RAT parameters, we consider r=500𝑟500r=500 meter, Z=10𝑍10Z=10, ω=1.8𝜔1.8\omega=1.8 MHz888With numerology 111, the pRB size is 360 KHz. However, for the ease of faster simulation, we considered that the pRB size is 5×36053605\times 360 KHz., n¯=1¯𝑛1\bar{n}=1, subcarrier spacing 303030 KHz and κ=0.5𝜅0.5\kappa=0.5 ms. We assume the gNB has 444 antennas, whereas the CVs have single antennas. For model training and testing, we use a) MNIST [56], b) FashionMNIST [57] c) German Traffic Sign Recognition Benchmark (GTSRB) [58] and d) CIFAR-101010 [59] datasets. We use a simple convolutional neural network (CNN) with two convolutional layers, each followed by max-pooling layers, one fully connected layer and the output layer. For the non-IID data distribution, we use symmetric Dirichlet distribution Dir​(α)Dir𝛼\mathrm{Dir}(\alpha) with the concentration parameter α𝛼\alpha and use a similar approach as in [4] to distribute the labels across the unique CVs. Note that a smaller α𝛼\alpha means the label distribution across CVs is more skewed.

To this end, we study the impact of different system parameters using the FashionMNIST dataset for FDPC and PDPC. We will also use the other three datasets to compare the performances later in Section V-D. Note that we have omitted the results of the VEFL and RAT parameter optimizations for brevity.

V-B Simulation Results: FDPC

V-B1 FDPC - Impact of Velocity and λ𝜆\lambda

First, we validate our aggregation rule’s necessity for different velocities. Note that in (26), if we put zero weight on the estimated sojourn period, then the server essentially aggregates the model weights solely based on the dataset sizes of the CVs. When the FEEL clients are stationary, it makes sense to aggregate the model parameters based on the dataset sizes. However, when the clients are mobile, which is the case for CVs, solely aggregating based on dataset size may not yield the best results. This is particularly true when mobility is relatively high. The expected sojourn period of the CV decreases as the velocity increases. Therefore, a CV has less time to perform its local iterations as it must offload the trained model before moving out of the gNB’s coverage area. This essentially means that the performance of the trained global model may not yield good test accuracy. A similar trend is also observed in our simulation results. Fig. 12 shows how test accuracy varies across the VEFL rounds for different CV velocities for α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1. We observe that the performance decreases when umaxsuperscriptumax\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}} increases. Note that the solid lines in the figures show the mean values, while the shaded strip is the standard deviation. These simulation results also reveal that the deviation also increases with increased velocity.

In addition, it is beneficial to put more weight on the expected sojourn period. Our results in Fig. 12 and Fig. 12 also validate this claim. When umax=0.45superscriptumax0.45\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=0.45 m/s, we observe that λ=0.8𝜆0.8\lambda=0.8 and λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1 yield nearly identical performance in Fig. 12. Besides, when umax=20.12superscriptumax20.12\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=20.12 m/s, λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1 clearly provides the best test accuracy, which is reflected in Fig. 12. Fig. 12 verifies that our proposed aggregation policy works for all umaxsuperscriptumax\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}s. Furthermore, the standard deviations in the test accuracy are also negligible for all velocities.

V-B2 FDPC - Impact of tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k)

The impact of the deadline threshold tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k) between two VEFL rounds can also affect the learning performance. Intuitively, having a smaller tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k) means the server can run more VEFL rounds within a fixed time duration. Therefore, the trained model’s test accuracy is expected to be better with a smaller tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k). However, although this holds at low velocity, it is not straightforward at a higher umaxsuperscriptumax\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}} since the short sojourn period may lead to a smaller lv​(k)subscript𝑙𝑣𝑘l_{v}(k). Therefore, under high mobility, the server shall carefully decide the deadline threshold tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k) to get a reasonably trained model from the participating CVs. Our simulation results also reveal similar trends in Fig. 12 and Fig. 12. Particularly, when umax=0.45superscriptumax0.45\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=0.45 m/s, we observe that tth=3superscripttth3\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}=3 s and tth=5superscripttth5\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}=5 s yield almost similar performances. However, at umax=20.12superscriptumax20.12\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=20.12 m/s, we observe that tth​(k)=3superscripttth𝑘3\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k)=3 s clearly does not provide better results over tth​(k)=5superscripttth𝑘5\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k)=5 s and tth​(k)=10superscripttth𝑘10\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k)=10 s. Furthermore, a shorter tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k) also causes more VEFL rounds, which causes more expenses for the server. Fig. 18 shows how the total cost ∑k=1K∑v=1Vt˘kξ​(lv​(k),ηv​(k))superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑣1subscript𝑉subscript˘𝑡𝑘𝜉subscript𝑙𝑣𝑘subscript𝜂𝑣𝑘\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{v=1}^{V_{\breve{t}_{k}}}\xi(l_{v}(k),\eta_{v}(k)) vary for different tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k). Here, we stress that a smaller tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k) can be desirable for the server if it requires a trained global model that delivers a certain level of accuracy quickly at the cost of higher expenses. As such, depending on its operational needs, it may choose the desired deadline threshold.

V-C Simulation Results: PDPC

Note that the length of subset 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k} is a design parameter that the system administrator can choose. Based on our simulation setting, we found that |𝒞k|=8subscript𝒞𝑘8|\mathcal{C}_{k}|=8 provides the best results for MNIST and GTSRB datasets, while |𝒞k|=10subscript𝒞𝑘10|\mathcal{C}_{k}|=10 and |𝒞k|=12subscript𝒞𝑘12|\mathcal{C}_{k}|=12 work best for the FashionMNIST and CIFAR-101010 datasets, respectively. Moreover, our framework is general, where the server can adjust this value in each VEFL round.

V-C1 PDPC - Impact of Velocity

We now validate that our PDPC solution is robust against different velocities. Recall that we maximize a weighted summation of lv​(k)subscript𝑙𝑣𝑘l_{v}(k)s, where we choose the weight based on expected sojourn periods and dataset sizes of the CVs. Particularly, since PDPC allows the server to choose the CVs at the beginning of the VEFL rounds, we put equal weights on the sojourn periods and the dataset sizes, i.e., λ¯=0.5¯𝜆0.5\bar{\lambda}=0.5 in (35). Therefore, a proper joint optimization for 𝟏​(v∈𝒞k)1𝑣subscript𝒞𝑘\mathbf{1}(v\in\mathcal{C}_{k}), lv​(k)subscript𝑙𝑣𝑘l_{v}(k) and ηv​(k)subscript𝜂𝑣𝑘\eta_{v}(k) can combat the effect of short sojourn periods under high mobility. Our simulation results also validate this. In Fig. 18, we observe that the test accuracies are very similar for umax=0.45superscriptumax0.45\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=0.45 m/s, umax=11.18superscriptumax11.18\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=11.18 m/s and umax=20.12superscriptumax20.12\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=20.12 m/s. Particularly, when umax=0.45superscriptumax0.45\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=0.45 m/s and the VEFL rounds are k=100𝑘100k=100, k=200𝑘200k=200, k=300𝑘300k=300 and k=400𝑘400k=400, the test accuracies are 76.71%percent76.7176.71\%, 79.19%percent79.1979.19\%, 81.17%percent81.1781.17\% and 82.53%percent82.5382.53\%, respectively. For the same VEFL rounds, when umax=11.18superscriptumax11.18\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=11.18 m/s, the test accuracies are 76.17%percent76.1776.17\%, 78.56%percent78.5678.56\%, 80.67%percent80.6780.67\% and 82.11%percent82.1182.11\%, respectively. Besides, when umax=20.12superscriptumax20.12\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=20.12 m/s, the test accuracies are 76.08%percent76.0876.08\%, 78.74%percent78.7478.74\%, 81.12%percent81.1281.12\% and 82.3%percent82.382.3\%, respectively.

Note that PDPC performs similarly to FDPC with respect to different tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k), which we skip presenting for brevity.

V-D Performance Comparisons

We now compare the performances of our proposed FDPC and PDPC VEFL schemes with the state-of-the-art FedProx[23] and anarchic federated averaging - cross-device (AFA-CD) [60] baselines. For FedProx and AFA-CD, we consider two cases, namely, (1) all constraints are present, and (2) no constraints are enforced. Note that the latter is the ideal case that does not consider any delay, energy, monetary or radio resource constraints. Besides, for the baselines with system constraints, we assume that the server expends an equal amount of its budget for all CVs. Furthermore, taking the maximum CPU frequencies ηvmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝜂𝑣max\eta_{v}^{\mathrm{max}}’s, the lv​(k)subscript𝑙𝑣𝑘l_{v}(k)’s are chosen to satisfy the time and energy constraints. Moreover, we use the same RAT solution for offloading the CVs’ trained models. Note that the baselines with constraints are expected to perform worse when the velocity increases since they do not consider mobility in the model weights aggregation. We also compare the results with the centralized ML, which serves as the performance upper bound as the server can access all training data.

To that end, we compare these schemes with umax=20.12superscriptumax20.12\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=20.12 m/s in Fig. 18. When VEFL rounds are k=200𝑘200k=200, k=300𝑘300k=300 and k=400𝑘400k=400, the test accuracies with FDPC are 78.91%percent78.9178.91\%, 81.43%percent81.4381.43\% and 81.77%percent81.7781.77\%, respectively. On the other hand, PDPC delivers 78.74%percent78.7478.74\%, 81.12%percent81.1281.12\% and 82.30%percent82.3082.30\% test accuracies for the same respective VEFL rounds. By contrast, for the same VEFL rounds, when all constraints are present, FedProx returns 35.89%percent35.8935.89\%, 39.94%percent39.9439.94\% and 45.07%percent45.0745.07\%, while AFA-CD yields 55.03%percent55.0355.03\%, 60.51%percent60.5160.51\% and 63.59%percent63.5963.59\% test accuracies. Moreover, in the ideal case, i.e., without (W/O) constraints, FedProx delivers 77.75%percent77.7577.75\%, 80.09%percent80.0980.09\% and 80.98%percent80.9880.98\%, and AFA-CD returns 56.26%percent56.2656.26\%, 59.04%percent59.0459.04\% and 63.19%percent63.1963.19\% test accuracies. These results suggest that our proposed FDPC and PDPC schemes significantly outperform the baselines. It is worth noting that FedProx W/O constraints performs similarly to our solutions with constraints, while the AFA-CD fails to achieve good performance. This is due to the fact that FedProx also incorporates a similar local loss function for the clients, whereas AFA-CD does not incorporate any proximal terms and employs a different aggregation rule. Besides, the gap with the centralized ML is expected due to the inherent nature of the system model. More specifically, all training data samples are distributed among the CVs without repetitions. As such, once a CV moves out of the communication area, its training data samples are no longer available. Moreover, these CVs may only perform a few local rounds before moving out of the gNB’s coverage.

Besides, unlike in the ideal case, under all system constraints, FedProx suffers from potential model divergence. In such a constrained case, notice that the best test accuracy of 55.06%percent55.0655.06\% is achieved with FedProx when k=81𝑘81k=81. However, 𝝎ksubscript𝝎𝑘\boldsymbol{\omega}_{k} does not converge and fluctuates rapidly, as shown in Fig. 18. It is even more evident in Fig. 18, which shows the failure rate of achieving a test accuracy of 70%percent7070\% for different umaxsuperscriptumax\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}. We can see that FDPC achieves a higher test accuracy than the accuracy threshold for all velocities after about 515151 VEFL rounds with probability 111. On the other hand, we notice a few oscillations with PDPC. Particularly, the probability of having a higher test accuracy than the threshold becomes one after about 515151 VEFL rounds, notwithstanding a 20%percent2020\% drop at VEFL round k=95𝑘95k=95. However, from k=96𝑘96k=96 onward, PDPC delivers a higher test accuracy than the threshold with probability 111. Contrary to these guaranteed performances with FDPC and PDPC, the performance of FedProx with constraints is unreliable. Even at low mobility, umax=0.45superscriptumax0.45\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=0.45 m/s, we observe that FedProx’s performance oscillates. This baseline shows that the test accuracy can be less than the threshold 20%percent2020\% of the time, even at VEFL round k=349𝑘349k=349 with relatively low mobile CVs. Furthermore, AFA-CD fails to achieve the desired 70%percent7070\% accuracy.

Although PDPC yields slightly higher performance oscillations than FDPC initially, it is still a practical solution in resource-constrained circumstances. To further study its benefits, we now examine the CCDF of pvsuc​(k)superscriptsubscriptp𝑣suc𝑘\mathrm{p}_{v}^{\mathrm{suc}}(k). Recall that for FDPC, FedProx and AFA-CD, all CVs with SLAs receive the global model and participate in the training process. However, due to mobility, some CVs may not finish even a single local iteration within the allocated deadline. Besides, the energy constraint can also potentially restrict some CVs from training and offloading their models. On the other hand, in PDPC, this can be mitigated by appropriately selecting the subset 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k}. In any case, if the server does not receive a CV’s local model within tth​(k)superscripttth𝑘\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}(k), it considers that as a failure. Our simulation results in Fig. 18 suggest that in all VEFL rounds, a CV successfully offloads its locally trained model to the server with at least 0.90.90.9 probability 97.3%percent97.397.3\%, 100%percent100100\%, 97.1%percent97.197.1\% and 97%percent9797\% percent of the times for FDPC, PDPC, FedProx and AFA-CD, respectively. Moreover, a CV has a success probability of at least 0.990.990.99 for 76.45%percent76.4576.45\% and 100%percent100100\% of the VEFL rounds, respectively, in FDPC, PDPC, and 76.25%percent76.2576.25\% of the VEFL rounds for FedProx and AFA-CD, with all constraints present.

PDPC not only guarantees a 100%percent100100\% trained models reception but also yields a lesser expense for the server. This is due to the fact that the server only needs to pay the fees to the selected CVs in the subset 𝒞ksubscript𝒞𝑘\mathcal{C}_{k}. Our simulation results in Fig. 18 show that, in a VEFL round, the server’s cost is less than 700700700 units for about 23.75%percent23.7523.75\%, 100%percent100100\%, 46.8%percent46.846.8\% and 47.3%percent47.347.3\% of the times, respectively, for FDPC, PDPC, FedProx and AFA-CD. Note that PDPC not only requires a lesser expense but also delivers near identical test accuracies to FDPC.

Table I shows the performance comparisons on MNIST, FashionMNIST, GTSRB and CIFAR-101010 datasets with the obtained global model after K=400𝐾400K=400 VEFL rounds when umax=20.12superscriptumax20.12\mathrm{u}^{\mathrm{max}}=20.12 m/s, tth=5superscripttth5\mathrm{t}^{\mathrm{th}}=5 s and Ξ​(k)=1000Ξ𝑘1000\Xi(k)=1000 units. Under the resource-constrained scenario, it can be observed that both FDPC and PDPC perform similarly while the baselines lag significantly. Furthermore, even without constraints, AFA-CD fails to perform reasonably in GTSRB and CIFAR-101010 datasets. Moreover, the proposed schemes achieve performance comparable to FedProx W/O constraints, which validates the effectiveness of our proposed solutions under extreme resource constraints.

VI Conclusion

A novel vehicular edge federated learning framework that leverages a 555G-NR RAT and the limited computation powers of the moving CVs is proposed in this work. Under delay, energy and cost constraints, first, subset CV selection, local iterations and CPU frequencies are jointly optimized given the estimated worst-case sojourn period and communication delay and cost. Then, the RAT parameters are jointly optimized using an online per-slot-based stochastic optimization technique. Extensive simulation results suggest that the server can combat high mobility by aggregating the trained model parameters using a weighted combination of sojourn periods and dataset sizes in FDPC, whereas by appropriately selecting a subset of CVs in PDPC. Moreover, the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art FedProx and AFA-CD algorithms under the same constraints in all the examined scenarios.
